newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-EU MONITORING ENGLISH SATELLITE DEAL.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-EU MONITORING ENGLISH SATELLITE DEAL.

text.p: Europe's competition commissioner Karel van Miert said on Thursday he was monitoring a television rights deal between BSkyB and the English premier league but has not called for a formal investigation.
A statement was issued clarifying Van Miert's position after the BBC put out a press release saying Van Miert had called for a probe in an interview with BBC radio.
"He (Van Miert) wants to point out that a distinction has to be made between the need to closely watch all such deals and formal investigations," the statement said.

"Such a formal investigation is presently underway as to the Dutch sports channel, especially as regards the seven-year duration of the contract and not as far as the BSkyB-Premier League is concerned," it added.

In August the European Commission launched a probe into a plan by the Dutch soccer association KNVB to give a new TV channel called Sport 7, which it partly owns, exclusive rights for seven years over premier and first division matches.
BSkyB sealed a 670 million pound ($1.07 billion) contract in June this year to buy the rights to transmit premier league matches live until 2001.

"As to the BSkyB-Premiership contract, Van Miert said that this is part of a more general monitoring exercise related to the overall phenomnenon of exclusive TV rights on sports events," the statement added.
In an interview broadcast on BBC radio on Thursday night, Van Miert said: "We have to look into the (BSkyB-Premiership) deal and also the duration of the contract."

Asked by the programme if he would intervene in the deal he replied, "We certainly will. We certainly will. And what should not happen is that those acquiring the rights will be in such a dominant position that they are going to impose the rules."
Last month Van Miert signalled his concern over long-term deals involving ever-larger sums of money in submissions to the European Parliament.
"There is this trend which seriously worries us that increasingly a few large groups can buy such (sports broadcasting) rights," he said.
BSkyB issued a statement criticing the BBC press release based on the interview, calling it a "blatant distortion of the facts".
